edu.iastate.cs228.hw3

Class DoublySortedList

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.iastate.cs228.hw3.DoublySortedList

extends java.lang.Object
    IMPORTANT: In the case of any minor discrepancy between the comments before a method and its description in the file proj3.pdf, use the version from the file.

    • Constructor Detail

      • DoublySortedList

        public DoublySortedList()
        Default constructor constructs an empty list. Initialize size. Set the fields nextN and previousN of headN to the node itself. Similarly, set the fields nextB and previousB of headB.

      • DoublySortedList

        public DoublySortedList(java.lang.String inventoryFile)
                 throws java.io.FileNotFoundException
        Constructor over an inventory file consists of lines in the following format Throws an exception if the file is not found. You are asked to carry out the following operations: 1. Scan line by line to construct one Node object for each fruit. 2. Create the two doubly-linked lists, by name and by bin number, respectively, on the fly as the scan proceeds. 3. Perform insertion sort on the two lists. Use the provided BinComparator and NameComparator classes to generate comparator objects for the sort.
        Throws:
        java.io.FileNotFoundException

      • DoublySortedList

        public DoublySortedList(int size,
                        Node headN,
                        Node headB)
        Called by split() and also used for testing. Precondition: The doubly sorted list has already been created.
        Parameters:
        size -
        headN -
        headB -

    • Method Detail

      • size

        public int size()

      • add

        public void add(java.lang.String fruit,
                int n)
         throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Add one type of fruits in given quantity (n). 1. Search for the fruit. 2. If already stored in some node, simply increase the quantity by n 3. Otherwise, create a new node to store the fruit at the first available bin. add it to both linked lists by calling the helper methods insertN() and insertB(). The case n == 0 should result in no operation. The case n < 0 results in an exception thrown.
        Parameters:
        fruit - name of the fruit to be added
        n - quantity of the fruit
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if n < 0

      • restock

        public void restock(java.lang.String fruitFile)
             throws java.io.FileNotFoundException,
                    java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        The fruit list is not sorted. For efficiency, you need to sort by name using quickSort. Maintain two arrays fruitName[] and fruitQuant[]. After sorting, add the fruits to the doubly-sorted list (see project description) using the algorithm described in Section 3.2 of the project description. Ignore a fruit if its quantity in fruitFile is zero.
        Parameters:
        fruitFile - list of fruits with quantities. one type of fruit followed by its quantity per line.
        Throws:
        java.io.FileNotFoundException
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the quantity specified for some fruit in fruitFile is negative.

      • remove

        public void remove(java.lang.String fruit)
        Remove a fruit from the inventory. 1. Search for the fruit on the N-list. 2. If no existence, make no change. 3. Otherwise, call the private method remove() on the node that stores the fruit to remove it.
        Parameters:
        fruit -

      • remove

        public void remove(int bin)
            throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Remove all fruits stored in the bin. Essentially, remove the node. The steps are as follows: 1. Search for the node with the bin in the B-list. 2. No change if it is not found. 3. Otherwise, call remove() on the found node.
        Parameters:
        bin -
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if bin < 1

      • sell

        public void sell(java.lang.String fruit,
                 int n)
          throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Sell n units of a fruit. Search the N-list for the fruit. Return in the case no fruit is found. Otherwise, a Node node is located. Perform the following: 1. if n >= node.quantity, call remove(node). 2. else, decrease node.quantity by n.
        Parameters:
        fruit -
        n -
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if n < 0

      • bulkSell

        public void bulkSell(java.lang.String fruitFile)
              throws java.io.FileNotFoundException,
                     java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Process an order for multiple fruits as follows. 1. Sort the ordered fruits and their quantities by fruit name using the private method quickSort(). 2. Traverse the N-list. Whenever a node with the next needed fruit is encountered, let m be the ordered quantity of this fruit, and do the following: a) if m < 0, throw an IllegalArgumentException; b) if m == 0, ignore. c) if 0 < m < node.quantity, decrease node.quantity by n. d) if m >= node.quanity, call remove(node).
        Parameters:
        fruitFile -
        Throws:
        java.io.FileNotFoundException
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

      • inquire

        public int inquire(java.lang.String fruit)
        Checks if the fruit is in stock.
        Parameters:
        fruit -
        Returns:
        quantity of the fruit (zero if not on stock)

      • printInventoryN

        public java.lang.String printInventoryN()
        Output a string that gets printed out as the inventory of fruits by names. The exact format is given in Section 5.1. Here is a sample: fruit quantity bin --------------------------- apple 50 5 banana 20 9 grape 100 8 pear 40 3

      • printInventoryB

        public java.lang.String printInventoryB()
        Output a string that gets printed out as the inventory of fruits by storage bin. Use the same formatting rules for printInventoryN(). Below is a sample: bin fruit quantity ---------------------------- 3 pear 40 5 apple 50 8 grape 100 9 banana 20

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

      • compactStorage

        public void compactStorage()
        This method rearranges the bins containing fruits to be consecutive, starting at 1, while maintaining their original storage order. To implement this method, you need only traverse the B-list

      • clearStorage

        public void clearStorage()
        Remove all nodes storing fruits from the N-list and the B-list. By setting the predecessors and successors of headN and headB to themselves.

      • split

        public Pair<DoublySortedList> split()
        Split the list into two doubly-sorted lists DST1 and DST2. Let N be the total number of fruit types. Then DST1 will contain the first N/2 types fruits in the alphabetical order. DST2 will contain the remaining fruit types. The algorithm works as follows. 1. Traverse the N-list to find the median of the fruits by name. 2. Split at the median into two lists: DST1 and DST2. 3. Traverse the B-list. For every node encountered add it to the B-list of DST1 or DST2 by comparing node.fruit with the name of the median fruit. DST1 and DST2 must reuse the nodes from this list. You cannot make a copy of each node from this list, and arrange these copy nodes into DST1 and DST2.
        Returns:
        two doubly-sorted lists DST1 and DST2 as a pair.

      • insertionSort

        public void insertionSort(boolean sortNList,
                          java.util.Comparator<Node> comp)
        Perform insertion sort on the doubly linked list with head node using a comparator object, which is of either the NameComparator or the Bincomparator class. Made a public method for testing by TA.
        Parameters:
        sortNList - sort the N-list if true and the B-list otherwise.
        comp -

      • quickSort

        public void quickSort(java.lang.String[] fruit,
                      java.lang.Integer[] quant,
                      int size)
        Sort an array of fruit names using quicksort. After sorting, quant[i] is the quantity of the fruit with name[i]. Made a public method for testing by TA.
        Parameters:
        size - number of fruit names
        fruit - array of fruit names
        quant - array of fruit quantities
